channel.title: [RESOLVED - DENIED] New Board: Programmer Autobiographies
channel.description:
This seems all too common...why not?
I'm willing to bet there's plenty of people who are interested in the lives of 9-14 year olds. There's clearly much to be known behind the hard-working individuals in the RuneScape 2 Development section.
Anyone agree?

item.title: [RESOLVED - DENIED] New Board: Programmer Autobiographies
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

That story is not a joke…

Read full topic

item.title: [RESOLVED - DENIED] New Board: Programmer Autobiographies
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:26, topic:538933”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=657769.msg4400740#msg4400740 date=1390584022]

[quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=657769.msg4400735#msg4400735 date=1390583621]

[quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=657769.msg4400728#msg4400728 date=1390582221]

No. How self-absorbed can you guys be?
Nobody gives a shit about the trials and tribulations faced by noobs; chronicling them is silly. It’s only time to let the world know that you’re doing something when you’re at a level that what you can do is cool/novel/innovative etc.
[/quote]Personally I believe a lot of people would love to read my autobiography of programming. The challenges I’ve faced have been difficult, but at the same time I’ve learned a lot and putting this work in writing would be an inspiration to any programmer.

Then why don’t you go post it on facebook.
[/quote]If you’re that keen you can follow my blog posts: http://blog.mattyw.net/

Why? I don’t even read 95% of the bullshit that’s on my facebook feed, so why would I waste my time reading your blog? I don’t care about your struggles that made you become the developer you are today. I don’t care what you had to do to gain access to a computer and the internet. What I care about is what you can do. And I care about how you use what you’ve learned.
I’ve seen more ‘dramatic’ stories about peoples backgrounds with technology than basically anything someone from mopar could produce without exaggeration or lies.
How about that kid in Africa that used junk to create a radio transmitter? His ‘background’ is surely more worse than the background of kids here on mopar.

Sure, we all have faced some form of a ‘hardship’ or some sort of issue while trying to become a programmer, but that’s life. Get over it.
[/quote]If you actually read my blog you would find that I was abandoned at birth in the African outback, and I had to earn a living by selling my body to tourists and the white men that came over for the mining industry. Once I earned my first $150 (probably worth around $180USD now) I bought my first computer… an Acorn 803-80. I used this to develop an enterprise-scale CMS which was eventually bought by Adobe for $2m USD. I now write multi-billion dollar software for BAE Systems and IBM, and act as a role model for the children growing up in my home town.[/quote]
lmaoooooooooooooo

Read full topic

item.title: [RESOLVED - DENIED] New Board: Programmer Autobiographies
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:25, topic:538933”][quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=657769.msg4400735#msg4400735 date=1390583621]

[quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=657769.msg4400728#msg4400728 date=1390582221]

No. How self-absorbed can you guys be?
Nobody gives a shit about the trials and tribulations faced by noobs; chronicling them is silly. It’s only time to let the world know that you’re doing something when you’re at a level that what you can do is cool/novel/innovative etc.
[/quote]Personally I believe a lot of people would love to read my autobiography of programming. The challenges I’ve faced have been difficult, but at the same time I’ve learned a lot and putting this work in writing would be an inspiration to any programmer.

Then why don’t you go post it on facebook.
[/quote]If you’re that keen you can follow my blog posts: http://blog.mattyw.net/

Why? I don’t even read 95% of the bullshit that’s on my facebook feed, so why would I waste my time reading your blog? I don’t care about your struggles that made you become the developer you are today. I don’t care what you had to do to gain access to a computer and the internet. What I care about is what you can do. And I care about how you use what you’ve learned.
I’ve seen more ‘dramatic’ stories about peoples backgrounds with technology than basically anything someone from mopar could produce without exaggeration or lies.
How about that kid in Africa that used junk to create a radio transmitter? His ‘background’ is surely more worse than the background of kids here on mopar.

Sure, we all have faced some form of a ‘hardship’ or some sort of issue while trying to become a programmer, but that’s life. Get over it.[/quote]If you actually read my blog you would find that I was abandoned at birth in the African outback, and I had to earn a living by selling my body to tourists and the white men that came over for the mining industry. Once I earned my first $150 (probably worth around $180USD now) I bought my first computer… an Acorn 803-80. I used this to develop an enterprise-scale CMS which was eventually bought by Adobe for $2m USD. I now write multi-billion dollar software for BAE Systems and IBM, and act as a role model for the children growing up in my home town.

Read full topic

item.title: [RESOLVED - DENIED] New Board: Programmer Autobiographies
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:24, topic:538933”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=657769.msg4400728#msg4400728 date=1390582221]

[quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=657769.msg4400725#msg4400725 date=1390581416]

No. How self-absorbed can you guys be?
Nobody gives a shit about the trials and tribulations faced by noobs; chronicling them is silly. It’s only time to let the world know that you’re doing something when you’re at a level that what you can do is cool/novel/innovative etc.
[/quote]Personally I believe a lot of people would love to read my autobiography of programming. The challenges I’ve faced have been difficult, but at the same time I’ve learned a lot and putting this work in writing would be an inspiration to any programmer.

Then why don’t you go post it on facebook.
[/quote]If you’re that keen you can follow my blog posts: http://blog.mattyw.net/[/quote]
Why? I don’t even read 95% of the bullshit that’s on my facebook feed, so why would I waste my time reading your blog? I don’t care about your struggles that made you become the developer you are today. I don’t care what you had to do to gain access to a computer and the internet. What I care about is what you can do. And I care about how you use what you’ve learned.
I’ve seen more ‘dramatic’ stories about peoples backgrounds with technology than basically anything someone from mopar could produce without exaggeration or lies.
How about that kid in Africa that used junk to create a radio transmitter? His ‘background’ is surely more worse than the background of kids here on mopar.

Sure, we all have faced some form of a ‘hardship’ or some sort of issue while trying to become a programmer, but that’s life. Get over it.

Read full topic
